title: What is the next big home trend? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m actually perplexed by this question, not because it’s not a good one, but because it’s so often asked. Part of me wants to raise a large banner and walk down the street in a design parade. The banner would read: “Forget the trends and be original!” I can’t emphasize enough the truth about good design and construction today unless we’re talking: decades of styles merging. Anything goes. If you have a sense of style yourself, or you find a designer who mixes styles, you’ll find this is a current ‘trend’, for lack of a better word, because it’s not really a trend on a grand scale due to the big box stores and what they’re showing. Yet it’s growing in favor. People who are downsizing need minimal furniture. People who are buying their first homes are stretching their budgets. The mid century modern era look became the rage today primarily because it’s easy to work with, clean looking and affordable, given there are so many renditions of it. It’s a break from the traditional styles we’ve seen over the last thirty years. But give it a few more years and the average family’s necessary lifestyle, of living minamally (the correct use of this modern style), isn’t easy to maintain. Then styles like the industrial era or Victorian shabby chic are adopted as well, which can be merged if designed well. I believe innovative, smart designers know that style doesn’t matter as much as how it works with the architecture of the home. That it works for the comfort of the occupants. It works with the other furnishings in a space. More important: it’s beautiful in its esthetic use and its functional use, inside the client’s own style. Not the style of the moment in the retail stores. If these three criterias are met, function and esthetics and personal style, then the trend of the day might be no trend. In other words: what matters more than anything is the artistic nature of the mix of furnishings and the quality of applications used for the interior architecture work. We are in the Original Era, even though the marketplace will seldom show this because it’s not as easy to sell in the box stores, or off the developer’s plans. Nevertheless, the “no trend” trend will prevail.
